debate_topic: You have 100 candidates, upon which there exists a total order. The candidates have appointments with you, one at a time, in a random order. From each interview, you can tell exactly how that candidate ranks amongst those you have already examined. At that point, you may either accept or reject the candidate. Any acceptance or rejection is permanent; no candidate, once rejected, may be reconsidered. Your objective is solely to accept the best candidate. What is the strategy for maximizing your probability of doing so, and what is that probability?
base_answer:
The optimal strategy to maximize the probability of accepting the best candidate in this scenario is known as the "Secretary Problem" or the "Marriage Problem." The solution to this problem is as follows:

Strategy:

1. Observe the first n/e (approximately 37%) of the candidates, where n is the total number of candidates (in this case, 100).
2. During this observation phase, do not accept any candidate.
3. After the observation phase, start accepting the next candidate who is better than all the candidates you have observed so far.

Probability of Success:

The probability of accepting the best candidate using this strategy is approximately 1/e, which is around 37%.

Explanation:

The reasoning behind this strategy is as follows:

1. The observation phase allows you to get a sense of the distribution of the candidates' rankings. By observing the first 37% of the candidates, you can estimate the quality of the best candidate.
2. After the observation phase, you start accepting the next candidate who is better than all the candidates you have observed so far. This ensures that you accept the best candidate among the remaining 63% of the candidates.

The probability of success is 1/e (approximately 37%) because the optimal stopping point is when the next candidate is better than all the previously observed candidates, which happens, on average, once every e (approximately 2.718) candidates.

This strategy is optimal because it balances the need to observe a sufficient number of candidates to estimate the quality of the best candidate, while also maximizing the probability of accepting the best candidate among the remaining candidates.
